pageContext.claim: “$17 billion with Canada — Canada says we broke even. But they don’t include lumber and they don’t include oil. Oh, that’s not. My friend Justin he says, 'No, no, we break even.' I said, ‘Yeah, but you’re not including oil, and you’re not including lumber.' When you do, you lose $17 billion.”
pageContext.analysis: In recounting a conversation with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, Trump gets his facts quite wrong. Trudeau said Canada had a total trade deficit with the United States while Trump insisted it was the other way around. In reality, the U.S. goods trade deficit with Canada was $12.1 billion in 2016, but the U.S. services trade surplus with Canada was $24.6 billion in 2016, according to the U.S. Trade Representative. That is an overall surplus of about $12 billion. So Trudeau was right, according to U.S. government data.
